column4: OK - I have 2TBs that I just put into a RAID5 (three drives - as such [http://lookpic.com/i/542/IvfLaw5W.png]. I want to put my fourth drive, the one with all the data I want preserved, added (grown?) to the RAID array. How do I do this?
it's hard to grow a raid group once it has been created.  You'll have to stage the data somewhere so that it is available to be merged after the filesystem is created and mounted.
- i'm so lost i don't know where to begin
when a raid group is initialized it will loose all the data in the group.
exactly.  You can stage all the data somewhere else.
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=408461
you can grow a file system that is built on LVM but only through concatination. (raid 0)
if you want to add a disk to a raid group then the data has to be re-striped over all the drives in the group.
current lunux md based ext4fs raid groups don't support that.
stage all the data somewhere else (cd, another drive something) make the new raid group.
- i might be able to get hold of a temp. holding space, but for hypothetical how would you do this?
copy the data back to the raid group.
how do i add my 1tb after i backup the data?
even if everything works perfectly you still need a backup.
familiarize yourself with the procedure for creating a raid group. decide on a plan that best meets your need. then implement. http://tldp.org/HOWTO/Software-RAID-HOWTO.html
if you have a disk controler that supports raid you can do it at that level too.
i don't think i have a hardware controller but my motherboard supports fake raid
i definitely want RAID 5 - i don't want to lose data
you could buy a device like the drobo that lets you add and move drives through proprietery magic.
- are you still around?
I've heard out of band that adding a drive to a raid5 might work.  I just would not want to do it without good backups first.
brjann from this channel overheard our conversation and asserted that it has worked for him.
